awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interactions Between Incipient Continental Rifting, Fluvial Systems, and Regional Climate in Southern Africa: The Okavango-Makgadikgadi Complex, Botswana
awd_abstract_narration:
The Okavango Rift Zone (ORZ) and Delta (OD), and the Makgadikgadi Paleo-Megalake (MPL) form a
dynamic system in northern Botswana, southern Africa, where tectonic activity, climate change,
sedimentation, vegetation, fauna, and human influences interact with each other at various spatial and
temporal scales. This award provides support for a multidisciplinary study of the interactions and feedbacks between incipient continental rifting, drainage patterns, and Neogene/Quaternary regional climate in the ORZ-OD-MPL complex. The objectives are to develop: (i) a structural and tectonic model of the ORZ-OD; (ii) chronologies for the evolution of the OD and infilling phases of the MPL; and (iii) histories of drainage basin expansions and contractions of the complex climate/vegetation in the OD-MPL, and the links, or lack thereof, between the ORZ, OD, and MPL.   The  overarching scientific question is: to what degree tectonics interacted with surface processes and climate in the ORZ-MPL system, and what feedback loops were involved in this interaction to control the environmental evolution of central southern Africa since the Miocene?

The PIs will use a combination of seismology and sediment cores to look at the geometry of the rift faults and sediment fill. The material from the cores will additionally be used to establish provenance of the sediment and build climate records. These two datasets from the cores will be used to assess the relative importance of climate (via variable erosion) versus tectonic control (river migration/capture, etc.) on sediment supply. A 2D numerical model will integrate these data to explore the effect of basin asymmetry and sediment loading and how these feedback into basin development via loading and strain localization.

por.por_cntn:
The Okavango Rift Zone (ORZ) and Delta (OD), and the Makgadikgadi Paleo-Megalake (MPL) form a dynamic system in southern Africa, where tectonic activity, climate change, and the natural environment interact with each other at various spatial and temporal scales. Southern Africa is almost blank in terms of understanding climate and hydrology before the last Ice Age, including during important intervals of human evolution. Despite the need to understand the hydrologic vulnerability of this semi-desertic region under future climate change, it remains one of the most difficult to model and predict due to lack of data. This project was a multidisciplinary study of the interactions and feedbacks between incipient continental rifting, drainage patterns, and Neogene/Quaternary regional climate in the Okavango Delta region.  Our research team has helped advance our understanding of southern African landscapes through interdisciplinary research and has also supported a diversifying workforce through skills development and training. Major efforts included seismic imaging of the Okavango Rift, obtaining long drill cores from the delta and paleolake that date back to the Miocene, developing research infrastructure in southern African paleoecology, and applying this to understanding long-term ecological change in the region.

Major delays were experienced in this project associated with the COVID-19 pandemic which forced postponing crucial fieldwork until near the end of the funding timeline for the project.  However, this team adapted to these setbacks by using other associated means of evaluating vegetation change in southern Africa.  This project supported a new assistant professor as she developed paleoecological research infrastructure. We used available, previously collected material from other sites in the region to both develop expertise in the regional pollen flora and determine changes in vegetation over the Holocene.  In addition, we compiled and curated existing published pollen data from southern Africa to help relaunch a database of pollen data that included many high-quality datasets from the region in order to understand abrupt change since the Last Ice Age.

Once fieldwork was completed, new seismic surveys of the Okavango Rift were completed in order to understand the subsurface structure and stratigraphy of the basin.  Additionally, drill cores were collected from two sites, one in the Makgadikgadi paleolake and another in the Okavango Delta.  Development of an age model is ongoing; however, initial cosmogenic dates suggest that both cores capture sediments deposited at ~5Ma, thus capturing a record of landscape evolution since the Miocene. Sedimentological data has now suggested that the timing of the formation of the massive lake that once occupied this now dry region, and pollen data from the cores suggest a decline in tree taxa since the Miocene, with pronounced drying during the Pliocene, which as important implications for ecosystems of hominin evolution.

This international project made impactful contributions in workforce development, skills training, and education for researchers and students.  This project supported an early career female professor develop a lab focused on southern African paleoecology. This project provided training opportunities for African scientists as well as US-based underrepresented minority students and researchers. Efforts to make available pollen data from southern Africa have empowered further research in the region by other students and scientists.
